The New York Times is available to
high school students across the U.S. — free.

Enjoy free digital access from April 6 to July 6.

Helping people understand the world has always been the cornerstone of our mission at The Times. And as the world continues to rapidly evolve, it’s more important than ever.

That’s why The Times is working with Verizon to provide high school students with a three-month free digital subscription from April 6 to July 6 — helping students stay connected to the world, even as they learn remotely.

What’s included:

  • Unlimited access to articles, videos and more on nytimes.com and in the New York Times app.
  • Lessons from The Learning Network featuring articles, photos, podcasts and more.

WHO CAN INVITE STUDENTS?

Teachers and administrators. All they need is a consolidated list of the students’ emails.

Parents and students, ask your school about getting invited.

Learn more in our Frequently Asked Questions.

Invite Your Students

Frequently Asked Questions

+
Who can participate?

U.S. high school students, teachers and administrators are eligible for three months of free access to The New York Times online, unless any of the following apply:

  • The student is under the age of 13.
  • Consent has not been obtained by school administrators for students in states that require it, in accordance with the Terms and Conditions.
  • The administrators, teachers and/or students are in a homeschool program.

+
I’m a high school student. How do I get access?

  • First, your high school administrator or teacher must register with The Times at nytimes.com/highschoolaccess.
  • Once they are verified, they will upload student email addresses to our secure portal.
  • You’ll then receive an email invitation to sign in and access The Times.
  • It’s important to note that you must use the email invitation to get the three free months. If you create an account directly on nytimes.com or in the New York Times app outside the email invitation, you won’t be able to access the free offer.

+
What happens to student emails?

The student emails provided to us as part of this program will not be shared outside The New York Times and our service providers. Students will also not receive personalized advertising on our site, app and The Learning Network newsletter.

If you haven’t already, take a look at our privacy policy — it contains more information about how we use and protect our readers’ information.

+
I don’t have access yet. What should I do?

School administrators or teachers must first register and invite students using nytimes.com/highschoolaccess. If you haven’t received an email invitation yet, please contact your school administrator directly.

+
I’m a school administrator/teacher. How do I participate?

School administrators and teachers are responsible for inviting students. Follow these steps:

  1. Click on “Invite Your Students” from the main landing page at nytimes.com/highschoolaccess.
  2. Create an account. If you already have a New York Times subscription with your primary email address, you’ll need to create a new account with a different email address.
  3. Enter the required information to verify that you are an administrator or teacher at your high school.
  4. Once verified, you’ll add students’ or teachers’ email addresses. Once your invitations are sent, you’ll receive an email confirmation.
  5. Students will then be invited via email automatically to access The Times online.
  6. Access for school administrators, teachers and students will last until July 6, 2020.

+
What access is included?

U.S. high school administrators, teachers and students have access to all journalism on nytimes.com or the New York Times app.

+
How long will my free subscription last?

Access lasts from April 6 to July 6, 2020.

+
I have more questions. Where can I find out more?

Contact us.
